newsitem.title: USA: Leading economic index rises 0.5 percent in February.
newsitem.headline: Leading economic index rises 0.5 percent in February.

text.p: The index of leading indicators, a key economic forecasting gauge, posted its largest increase in a year in February, a business research group said Tuesday, suggesting continued strong economic growth.

The Conference Board said the index rose by 0.5 percent in February after a 0.3 percent gain in January. The February rise in the index, which is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, was the largest since a 0.9 percent rise last February, the business group said.

The February increase was slightly higher than the 0.4 percent rise forecasted by Wall Street analysts. The stronger-than-expected gain was the latest in a string of recent indicators suggesting the economy is picking up speed.

The Federal Reserve last week boosted short-term interest rates by a quarter percentage point, its first increase in more than two years, and cited the risk that strong demand might fire up inflationary wage and price rises.
Over the six months from August to February, the index increased by 1.1 percent, the private business group said.

It said that nine of 10 components of the leading index rose in February. The largest contributors to the rise were a drop in unemployment claims, a slowdown in deliveries, which suggested that suppliers were having a harder time meeting demand, and stock prices, which fell sharply in March.
